did.abstract: Harlan Henthorne Hatcher (1898-1998) was president of the University of Michigan from 1951 to 1967. The papers span the years 1837-1998 and document Dr. Hatcher's University of Michigan presidency, Ohio State University career, literary career, organizational involvement, personal life, and family history. Includes correspondence, newspaper clippings, manuscripts, speeches, yearly datebooks, oral history interview transcripts, magnetic audio tape recordings, an audiocassette recording, and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were transferred from the President's Office (donor no. 343) and from Harlan and Anne Hatcher and their family (donor no. 4589).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Harlan Henthorne Hatcher Papers, 1837-1998, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Harlan Henthorne Hatcher was best known in his roles as author, educator, and university administrator. He published over seventeen books, numerous short stories, and many essays. At Ohio State University he served as an English Instructor, Assistant Professor of English, Professor of English, Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences, and Vice-President. Hatcher served as President of the University of Michigan from 1951 to 1967.

Dr. Hatcher was born on September 9, 1898 to Robert E. Hatcher and Malinda B. (Leslie) Hatcher of Ironton, Ohio. He attended Ohio State University from 1919-1927, receiving his bachelor's, master's and doctoral degrees in American Literature. In 1925 he completed post-doctoral work at the University of Chicago. Later, Dr. Hatcher spent a year in Italy, France, and England studying the Renaissance.

Harlan Hatcher spent much of his career at Ohio State University. He was an English instructor from 1922-1928, Assistant Professor of English from 1928 to 1932, Professor of English from 1932-1944, Dean of the College of Arts and Sciences from 1944 to 1948, and Vice-President of Ohio State University from 1948 to 1951.

In addition, Dr. Hatcher had an active professional life outside of the university. He wrote over seventeen books about the people, the history, and the geology of Michigan, Ohio, and Kentucky in addition to the subject of English Literature. Several of his short stories and essays were published in journals. In 1937 and 1938 Dr. Hatcher directed the Ohio branch of the Federal Writers Project, and he was the editor of their final product, The Ohio Guide. From 1938 to 1944 he wrote a weekly book critic column in the Columbus Citizen. He was the Editorial Advisor for College English from 1938 to1948, and was guest editor for several other publications. Dr. Hatcher was also involved in the military. He was a U.S. Army Private in 1918 and a Naval Reserve Lieutenant from 1942 to 1944. He served as a V-5 Instructor at the Pre-Flight School in Chapel Hill, North Carolina in 1944.

In 1951 Harlan Hatcher became president of the University of Michigan, a position he held until 1967. Under his leadership, enrollment more than doubled and the budget nearly quadrupled. He oversaw the development of North Campus and the regional campuses in Flint and Dearborn. He revolutionized the university's library system with the establishment of the Undergraduate Library, which was open long hours and had open-shelf access to books.

Dr. Hatcher was an active participator in organizations. His Faculty Personnel Record for the University of Michigan names membership or involvement in over eighty-five organizations through the 1960s. He dedicated his retirement to the problems of pollution and urbanization of the Great Lakes. He was president of the Developing Great Lakes Megalopolis Research Project (DGLMRP), he was on the board of directors for the Center for the Great Lakes (CFGL), and he was a trustee of the Great Lakes Foundation.

Dr. Hatcher's first wife, Frank (Dot) Wilson Colfax, predeceased him. He married Anne Gregory Vance in 1942. They had two children, Robert Leslie and Anne Linda. Harlan Hatcher died in 1998, at the age of ninety-nine.

scopecontent.p: The Harlan Henthorne Hatcher Papers document his University of Michigan presidency, Ohio State University career, literary career, organizational involvement, personal life, and family history. The collection spans the years 1837-1998, with the bulk of the materials covering 1891-1986. It includes correspondence, newspaper clippings, manuscripts, speeches, yearly datebooks, oral history interview transcripts, magnetic audio tape recordings, an audiocassette recording, and photographs. The collection is strongest in its documentation of Dr. Hatcher's presidency at the University of Michigan, especially in correspondence and speeches. Documentation is weakest on the subjects of his Ohio State University career before 1944 and organizational involvement before 1967. The collection may be useful to researchers interested in the history of the University of Michigan from 1951-1967, the duties of university administrators and their spouses, authors of the 1920's to 1950's, and environmental activism in Michigan in the 1970's and 1980's.

The Harlan Hatcher collection has been divided into two subgroups of files: those which were created or accumulated from his tenure as president of the University of Michigan (1951-1967) and those materials (mainly personal) dated either prior to or subsequent to Hatcher's presidential years.

The library, as archives of the University of Michigan, is the repository for all of the files of its presidents. For historic reasons, all of the papers of presidents up to and including Harlan Hatcher have been treated as personal collections and cataloged under the name of the president. Beginning with Hatcher's successor - Robben Fleming - and continuing to the present, the files of individuals occupying the president's office have been considered both personal and institutional. Records created from an individual's responsibility as president, usually materials from the years when he was president, are treated as office files and have been cataloged as part of the University of Michigan President's Office record group. Materials from either before or after an individual's tenure as president have been treated separately and have been cataloged under that president's name.

scopecontent.p: Hatcher is the last president whose collection contains a mixture of both personal and office files. The University of Michigan Presidency subgroup is the largest portion of the collection comprising 59 linear feet of correspondence, memoranda, reports, speeches, and other materials on which he acted or which crossed his desk as president. The University of Michigan Presidency subgroup is divided into four series: Yearly Correspondence Files, Organizational Responsibilities/Special Events and Issues as President, Ceremonial/Public Role as President, and Topical Files.

The Yearly Correspondence File (47 linear ft.; 1951-1967) series is the largest series in the collection and is further divided into chronological subseries for each academic year. Each year is comprised of a single alphabetical sequence of papers on which Hatcher acted or transferred to another university administrator for action. Included as well are the communications which faculty, departments and other units, alumni, legislators, citizens, and other individuals had with the president.

scopecontent.p: The Organizational Responsibilities/Special Activities as President series (6.3 linear ft.; 1953-1967) is the title given to those categories of files, kept separate by the president's office from the Yearly Correspondence Files and covering an extended period of time. These files cover Hatcher's participation as representative of the University of Michigan with different academic and professional organizations. These include the Michigan Council of State College Presidents, the Midwestern University Research Association, the Commission on the Education of Women of the American Council on Education, the Institute for Defense Analyses, the Citizens Committee on Higher Education, the Council for Financial Aid to Education, the Joint Office of Institutional Research, and the National Association of State Universities and Land-Grant Colleges. In addition, this series includes files relating to the celebration of the university's sesquicentennial, both ceremonial observances and lectures and fund-raising opportunities. Lastly, within this series are those letters and other working materials accumulated in response to the changing of the name of Michigan State College to Michigan State University in 1955.

scopecontent.p: The Ceremonial/Public Role as President (4.7 linear ft.; 1951-1967) is a smaller series pertaining to Hatcher's inaugural, his engagement (or invitation) files, his speeches as president, and the files accumulated from the travels he made as president.

scopecontent.p: The final series in the President's Files subgroup is Topical Files (1 linear ft.; 1951-1967). This series contains a miscellanea of files on particular topics. These materials were accessioned after the initial receipt of Hatcher's Yearly Correspondence Files and were undoubtedly kept separate for personal reasons. Some of these files might have been maintained in Hatcher's residence and not his office. The topics are self-explanatory.

did.unittitle: Appointment as President, University of Michigan 1951

scopecontent.p: The second subgroup in the collection is Pre-and Post-Presidential Files. The subgroup is arranged around facets of Dr. Hatcher's life into six series: Personal/Biographical, Writings, Ohio State University, U.S. Military, Retirement, and Audio and Visual Materials.

The Personal/Biographical series (2.3 linear ft., 1837-1997) consists of autobiographical writings, biographical materials, and correspondence and other documents about the Hatcher family history. It is arranged into five subseries: Miscellaneous, Yearly Datebooks, Interviews, Autobiographical Writings, and Family.

The Miscellaneous subseries contains Vitae, Degrees and Awards, and Memorabilia From Youth. This includes resumes, a faculty personnel record, passport applications, honorary degrees and awards,and drawings and papers from Harlan Hatcher's youth in Ironton, Ohio.

odd.p: (see also honorary degree in oversize folder Ac)

scopecontent.p: The Yearly Datebooks subseries consists of a chronological run of datebooks documenting daily aspects of Dr. Hatcher's life from 1929-1997. Common entries consist of activities, weather, and current events. Some years are more detailed than others.

The Interviews subseries includes transcripts of two interviews. In the first transcript, Harlan Hatcher discusses his father. The second transcript, the oral history conducted by Enid H. Galler is more extensive and discusses a variety of indexed topics.

did.unittitle: Oral History Conducted by Enid H. Galler 1991-1992

scopecontent.p: The Autobiographical Writings subseries contains Dr. Hatcher's own reflections on his life. Some of these writings are addressed to members of his family while others are in manuscript form.

did.unittitle: To Anne Gregory Hatcher, On First Marriage February 4, 1997
Robert E. Hatcher and the Early Years

scopecontent.p: The Family subseries contains poetry, correspondence, and genealogical materials by and about various members of the Hatcher family and close friends. Of particular note are the files on Anne Gregory Vance Hatcher, Harlan's wife. She was involved in arranging and hosting many social functions at the University of Michigan during her husband's presidency. Also of note are the love letters between Harlan's parents, Robert E. Hatcher and Malinda B. Leslie, in 1891 and 1892. They began corresponding after Robert visited Malinda's parents' home in Coal Run, Pike County, Kentucky. Because Robert lived in Coal Grove, Lawrence County, Ohio, much of their relationship until their marriage is documented in these letters. A related run of correspondence are the letters to Harlan from his wife, Anne Gregory, in January and February of 1943 while Harlan was serving as a V-5 instructor in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. Also of note are the letters between Harlan and his mother from 1919 to 1948.

scopecontent.p: The Writings series (2.4 linear ft., 1918-1991) documents Harlan Hatcher's efforts at drafting and publishing his writings and the public's reaction to the final product. The series is divided into six subseries: Coursework, Poetry, Books, Essays and Short Stories, Book Reviews by Harlan Hatcher, and Miscellaneous. For autobiographical writings, see the Personal/Biographical series.
The Coursework subseries contains papers Dr. Hatcher wrote in the process of attending high school and Ohio State University.

did.unittitle: Master's Thesis: "the Plays of Arthur Wing Pinero as a Reflection of the Growth of the Modern English Drama," 1923

scopecontent.p: The Poetry subseries contains the relatively few documented attempts Harlan Hatcher made at this genre. It is unclear whether the poems were published.
The Books subseries includes correspondence, manuscripts, publicity materials, newspaper clippings, and reviews for many of Harlan Hatcher's published books.

did.unittitle: Publicity Materials: Order Form and Radio Script September 1940
A Century of Iron and Men, 1950
Creating the Modern American Novel, Correspondence and Reviews, 1933-1936, 1964-1965
"The Judge Bardwell Novel," Partial Manuscript, Unpublished?, Circa 1936
Modern American Dramas, Correspondence and Publicity Materials, 1941-1950
The Ohio Guide, Federal Writers Project

unittitle.title: A Pictorial History of the Great Lakes

did.unittitle: About the Great Lakes Megalopolis Project 1975

scopecontent.p: The Essays and Short Stories subseries consists of alphabetically ordered manuscripts, entire journals containing Harlan Hatcher's writings, and excerpted articles from journals containing his writings.

did.unittitle: Border Between United States and Canada
"The Meaning of the War for Americans," after 1941
"Ohio in the Literature of the Twentieth Century"
"On Not Having Read James Branch Cabell"
College English Journal, Articles and Correspondence, 1939-1940
Journals in which Harlan Hatcher Was Published
Articles from Journals in which Harlan Hatcher Was Published 1930-1975

scopecontent.p: The Book Reviews by Harlan Hatcher subseries contains correspondence, the weekly "Books and Authors" Column from Citizen Magazine, and typed reviews written by Harlan Hatcher. Most of Hatcher's book reviewing took place from 1935 to 1947.

did.unittitle: "Books and Authors" Column in Citizen Magazine

scopecontent.p: The Miscellaneous subseries contains papers that would not fit in the genres described in the other subseries. Included are story ideas and general correspondence.

The Ohio State University series (5.3 linear ft., 1919-1951) covers all topics having to do with Harlan Hatcher's career at Ohio State University. It contains seven subseries: Teaching Materials, Clippings, Correspondence, Organizations, Speeches, the Dean's Personal and Professional File, and the Vice-President's Personal and Professional File.
The Teaching Materials subseries includes information about some of the courses Harlan Hatcher taught while at Ohio State University.

did.unittitle: Explications: Emerson, Whitman, Hazlitt, et. al

scopecontent.p: The Clippings subseries documents Harlan Hatcher's appearance in newspapers and other publications during his tenure at Ohio State University.

did.unittitle: 1931-1947 from Head of English Department to Dean of College of Arts and Sciences

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence subseries contains Dr. Hatcher's Ohio State University correspondence from 1923 to 1951, with an emphasis on before 1944. Official correspondence from 1944 to 1951 may be in the Dean's Personal and Professional File or the Vice President's Personal and Professional File in this series. Correspondence with family and close friends can be found in the Personal/Biographical series. Correspondence relating directly to Harlan Hatcher's published works are in the Writings series.

did.unittitle: Position Offers: Arkansas, Cornell, Hunter College, Circa 1938-1945

scopecontent.p: The Organizations subseries consists mainly of correspondence with organizations including the Modern Language Association, the St. Lawrence Association, and the University Guild.

did.unittitle: St. Lawrence Association, Publications and Correspondence 1949-1950

scopecontent.p: The Speeches subseries includes newspaper clippings, correspondence, programs, transcripts from radio broadcasts, and the text of speeches from 1930 to 1950.

did.unittitle: Tribute to Lynn Wilbur St. John January 1937
President Bevis Inaugural Dinner 1940 Retirement, Dinner, 1956
President George W. Rightmire Retirement undated
OSU Lecture Series, "The Romantic Period in Poetry," undated

scopecontent.p: The Dean's Personal and Professional Files, 1944-1948; and the Vice-President's Personal and Professional Files, 1948-1951 consist of alphabetically arranged topical files for each academic year. These files were kept in their original order and therefore there is some content overlap with other subseries such as correspondence and organizations.

did.unittitle: Vice President's Personal and Professional File

scopecontent.p: The Dean's Personal and Professional Files, 1944-1948; and the Vice-President's Personal and Professional Files, 1948-1951 consist of alphabetically arranged topical files for each academic year. These files were kept in their original order and therefore there is some content overlap with other subseries such as correspondence and organizations.

The U.S. Military series (.3 linear ft., 1942-1944) contains notebooks from Harlan Hatcher's military service from 1942 to 1944. Included is a copy of "How To Stay Alive," edited by Harlan Hatcher in 1943. Photographs from this period are included in the Audio and Visual Materials series.

did.unittitle: "How To Stay Alive," 1943 edited by Harlan Hatcher

scopecontent.p: The Retirement series (2 linear ft., 1968-1998) consists of five subseries: Clippings, Correspondence, Organizations, Speeches, and Travel.

The Organizations subseries contains files from Harlan Hatcher's heavy involvement in organizations during his retirement. The largest represented organizations are the Center for the Great Lakes, of which Dr. Hatcher was on the board of directors in the 1980's, and the Developing Great Lakes Megalopolis Research Project, of which Harlan Hatcher was president.

did.unittitle: Committee of Responsibility; Spaulding for Children 1967-1970
Developing Great Lakes Megalopolis Research Project
Sugar Bush Association 1959-1975 (Property in Leland, MI)

scopecontent.p: The Speeches subseries contains correspondence; clippings; programs; and the text of speeches that Dr. Hatcher gave during his retirement, grouped into seven categories: Anniversaries and Dedications, Commencements, Memorial Services, Education, University of Michigan, Environment, and Michigan and Ohio History.

"Problems in Our Society: The Air," Panel Discussion, n.d
Pioneering Spirit Symposium, Northwest Technical College, Archibold, OH May 1975

scopecontent.p: The Travels subseries contains documentation of two vacations Dr. Hatcher took during his retirement: The Alumni World Tour in 1968 and a trip to China and Japan in 1977.
The Audio And Visual Materials series (.7 linear ft.) is divided into two subseries: Photographs and Audio Recordings of Speeches.
The Photographs series is arranged into the following categories: Portraits, Writings, Ohio State University, U.S. Navy and U.S. Army, The University of Michigan, Organizations, and Immediate Family.

scopecontent.p: The Audio Recordings of Speeches subseries contains two magnetic tapes: WIU Commencement Address, June 4, 1959; and Battelle Auditorium, January 14, 1970. There is also an audio cassette recording of a speech at Inglis House, about the Federal Writer's Project and The Ohio Guide, circa 1993.
